comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06] At a rough guess, sometime in the mid 1950s. Possibly mid-week judging from the rather typical week-day crowd on the beach. This is very much the Manly in which I grew up! Sadly the harbour pool (the gift of the Port Jackson and Manly Steamship Company) was destroyed on the evening of 24 May 1974 when a huge storm and high tides lashed the area.

See Corinneski's picture here:

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/corinneski/9159000750/]

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] That looks like a mighty big storm - scary stuff!

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: So Michael's arch and Michael's cave are not the same thing. Interesting.

comment.author: 64403351@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] I think it's earlier. Most of the buses have highly contrasting colours, which would suggest the older red and cream livery. Only a couple are in the new green and cream (which didn't contrast as much in B&W photos). The last red repaints were in September 1946 with a big effort to start green repaints the following month. My gut feeling is the photo is from the summer of 1946-47.

The funnels give the ferry away as either the SS Dee Why or SS Curl Curl.

comment.author: 21624712@N07
comment._content: mich_sydney, it certainly was a very big storm and extremely scary. We had waves breaking on the building in which we lived on the eastern side of Manly Cove.
